qas.question: What two countries argued over credit for the discovery of Neptune?
Who ultimately deserved credit for the discovery of Neptune?
Who questioned Adams's claim to co-discovery of Neptune?
Who did not deserve credit to co-discovery of Neptune?
Who predicted Neptune's place and convinced astronomer's to search for it?

Who bought the credit to co-discovery of Neptune?

context: In the wake of the discovery, there was much nationalistic rivalry between the <a0_0><b5_0><b10_0>French and the British<b10_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> over who deserved credit for the discovery. Eventually, <b6_0>an international consensus<b6_0/> emerged that both <a1_0><b11_0>Le Verrier and Adams<b11_0/><a1_0/> jointly deserved credit. Since 1966, <a2_0><b7_0><b12_0>Dennis Rawlins<b12_0/><b7_0/><a2_0/> has questioned the credibility of Adams's claim to co-discovery, and the issue was re-evaluated by <b9_0>historians<b9_0/> with the return in 1998 of the "<b8_0>Neptune papers<b8_0/>" (historical documents) to the Royal Observatory, Greenwich. After reviewing the documents, they suggest that "<a3_0><b13_0>Adams<b13_0/><a3_0/> does not deserve equal credit with <a4_0>Le Verrier<a4_0/> for the discovery of Neptune. That credit belongs only to the person who succeeded both in predicting the planet's place and in convincing astronomers to search for it."
